items.title: tablib no longer able to import Google Docs exported xlsx
items.body:
tablib used to be able to read xlsx files exported from Google Docs just fine.  Now it fails with InvalidDimensions if not all columns in the spreadsheet are populated with values.  For example, download [this](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1EhVz1i8s7j3tRgj9pm6mMD-cJx5jkZSY-ItmypVbUog/edit?usp=sharing) spreadsheet as xlsx (also attached below) and then try to read it like this:

`python3 -c "import tablib; tablib.Databook().load(open('test.xlsx', 'rb').read(), 'xlsx')"`

and it'll result in an InvalidDimensions exception.  The problem seems to be due to the fact that the first row has values in 2 columns, but the second row has an empty cell in the second column.  I'm guessing something changed in the way Google exports the xlsx files?
[test.xlsx](https://github.com/jazzband/tablib/files/4547849/test.xlsx)

items.title: xlsx import reads cell formulas instead of values
items.body:
When importing an Excel xlsx file it reads the cell formulas instead of the cell values.

I think when importing an Excel spreadsheet it's the values that would be wanted and not the formulas?

For example, if a cell has the formulas '=SUM(A1:A3)' it will read that string instead of the calculated number in Excel.

Passing data_only=True to openpyxl's load_workbook will load the cell values instead of formulas.

I created a pull request that does this
https://github.com/jazzband/tablib/pull/461

items.title: Dependencies removed from this project
items.body:
Hi, I realised that with the new version, the dependencies were removed (I think here: https://github.com/jazzband/tablib/issues/421) that caused a problem in one of our services, easily fixed by fixing the version to `0.14.0`, but I was wondering if the point of this project is to be completely generic and not relying on anything unless the user needs to, or if you will have some requirements.

I'm talking specifically about the `odfpy` requirement, but it'd be good to know if you plan on being dependency-less, so I can amend our service the right way.

PS: We're using `tablib` through django-import-export

UPDATE: Here's others talking about the same problem: https://github.com/django-import-export/django-import-export/issues/1064

items.title: Deprecate the TSV format

items.title: Load formats "on-demand"
items.body:
When  you `import tablib` in a not-too-recent system, you have to wait a bit (~5 seconds on my system), mainly due to all libraries used by all tablib formats being loaded at startup even if they are never used.

I'd suggest to only load the format files/libraries when the format is required by an import or export.

items.title: Render more formats optional
items.body:
When you install tablib, a rather big numbers of dependencies are automatically installed. It may not be a big deal on performant system, but still I think we should not force users to install dependencies for formats they may never use.

The downside of optional deps is that the install command is a bit more complicated, and requires the user to think a bit of desired formats. (e.g. `pip install tablib[xlsx, ods, yaml]`).
The formats that could be optional (= require dependencies) are: `xls`, `xlsx`, `odf`, `yaml`, `html` (and `dbf` when we'll succeed in externalizing it).

items.title: Release 0.14.0
items.body: @hugovk Can you check the current code (and HISTORY) and tell me if you think we could release 0.14.0 now? I'd just like to add that the 0.14.x series will be the last supporting Python 2. Would you like to lead the release process?

items.title: Drop support for Python 2
items.body:
Python 2 reaches end-of-life on **2020-01-01**.

See https://python3statement.org for a list of projects which have pledged to drop support for Python 2 on or before its EOL.

I'd like to suggest making a release soonish with the recent changes that still supports Python 2.7, and then drop it.

That'll allow newer features of Python to be used, and also some vendored code  can be removed (eg. https://github.com/jazzband/tablib/pull/362#issuecomment-538104111) and deal with some other issues (eg. https://github.com/jazzband/tablib/pull/268#issuecomment-473651820).

items.title: Delete Pipfile.lock?
items.body:
I understand the merits of committing a Pipfile.lock file is subject to debate, but as almost all our dependencies are now unpin, I don't see a good reason to keep it.
@jdufresne, any input?

items.title: Merge develop and master branch
items.body: We plan to remove the develop branch at some point. We should compare the branches and possibly merge to master some develop commits which have not been integrated until now.

items.title: Tablib fails to import dates from xlsx
items.body:
Given an Excel xlsx file containing:

| Integer | String | Float  | Date           |
|---------:|-------|-------:|--------------|
|          1 | abc     |   1.2   | 10/08/2019 |

OpenPyXL makes some sensible choices on data types:
```python
import openpyxl
wb = openpyxl.load_workbook(filename = 'tablib_test.xlsx')
[cell.value for cell in wb.active[2]]
```
> [1L, u'abc', 1.2, datetime.datetime(2019, 8, 10, 0, 0)]

However, tablib ends up with Excel's internal date format representation and, as far as I can see, there is no way to detect that this data was originally a date:
```python
import tablib
data = tablib.Dataset().load(open('tablib_test.xlsx').read())
data[0]
```
> (1.0, u'abc', 1.2, 43687.0)

Tested with tablib 0.13.0 and 0.12.1

items.body:
The last version on PyPI is 0.12.1 from September 1st, 2017. 

There were a lot of changes to the code since then, including, crucially, https://github.com/kennethreitz/tablib/pull/296 which fixes a long-standing bug that has been preventing tablib from working properly for more than a year (openpyxl 2.5.0, which turned the warning into a breaking change, was released on January 24th, 2018).

I see that a few people have been bringing new life to this project, please consider pushing a new release to PyPI as part of this!

items.title: Loading big CSV files is slow due to sniffing
items.body:
I'm using tablib to load a large-ish (2.5MB, 3k rows) CSV file.

tablib's format detector uses `csv.Sniffer` to see if the file is CSV, but passes the entire data stream to the sniffer. In my case this causes the format detection to take about 5 minutes. The impression I'm getting from [the official CSV module docs](https://docs.python.org/3/library/csv.html#csv.Sniffer) is that `Sniffer` should be passed only a small sample of data, e.g. 1kb, not the whole file.

I propose passing only the first 1kb of data to the `Sniffer` at https://github.com/kennethreitz/tablib/blob/5a359ba4def1611b34df003bec58439a125d4e56/tablib/formats/_csv.py#L54 
This is same amount as shown in the official docs.

Can do PR if this approach sounds good.

items.title: export "cli" format
items.body:
Hi,

Would you consider an `export` format suited for cli purposes as well, like

1. the `simple` table format as described here https://pypi.org/project/tabulate/
2. the same format is used by all tools from HashiCorp, Consul, Vault, etc.

in other words, it is a familiar more or less format.

Example:
```
Path          Type         Description
----          ----         -----------
cubbyhole/    cubbyhole    per-token private secret storage
kv/           kv           n/a
secret/       kv           key/value secret storage
sys/          system       system endpoints used for control, policy and debugging
```

items.title: Need for 2nd maintainer
items.body:
As @hugovk mentioned in PR #310, we have a maintainer issue with tablib (similarly with `records`).

Facts:
- @kennethreitz is Development Lead (592 commits)
- @iurisilvio is Core Contributor (14 commits)
- There are 20 authors mentioned in AUTHORS.
  - @lbeltrame and @durden 13 commits
  - @f4nt, @claudep and @msabramo 5 commits or more
  - 10 other with 3 commits
  - 6 others with 2 commits
  - 47 other with 1 commit
- Issues: 107 closed, 68 open
  - last 25 open issues are younger than 12 months
- PR 135 closed, 18 open
  - 16 open PRs are younger than 12 months
  - good number of those PRs seem to fix open issues
  - last PR accepted is around 7 month old
- downloads/pip installs
  - 48 thousands in last 30 days (see table in PR #310)
- last version is `0.12.1` released on Sep 1, 2017

To summarize:
- There is clear interest on `tablib` from users as well as from contributors.
- Maintenance got somehow stuck since September last year.

Proposal for next actions:
- @kennethreitz , @iurisilvio are you willing to accept another maintainer or even hand over to someone?
- others: is there anyone feeling like becoming maintainer?

items.title: xlsx casting all types to string | unicode
items.body:
```python
head = ('integer', 'float', 'text', 'integer as text')
data = [(123, 3.14, 'hello world', '987',),]
data = tablib.Dataset(*data, headers=head)
f = open('types.xlsx', 'wb')
f.write(data.xlsx) # works correctly with data.xls
```

**Expected behaviour:**

Exported file would have values in the same type as defined above.
Eg. integer => integer,  float => float, string => string

**What is happening**

All types are casted to strings
integer => string,  float => string, string => string

This is a problem when people what to do some counting operation with the resulting `xlsx` as it will break, and needs to be changed inside the document.

**Where and when is the origin**

* Introduced in `version  0.11.5` in [commit](https://github.com/kennethreitz/tablib/pull/221/files#diff-e084e40878a6d2614b831e70c87fb140R142) by adding unicode() around `col`
* imho a silent BC, as it changes functionality

Internally unicode function return a string object, or for python3 compatibility is casted to string object:
```python
# inside compat.py
if is_py3:
    unicode = str;
```

**Fix**

Leave handling of types for `openpyxl` and remove unicode wraps around values.

This fix was proposed and merged already in #309, but it was done again develop branch that is quite outdated and not compatible with python3.
Also when exporting to `xls` it works correctly as unicode wrapping wasn't added here.

When `ujson` is installed, [export_set](https://github.com/kennethreitz/tablib/blob/46102d4be718ee6fd6c003c1387df7c940e65b2c/tablib/formats/_json.py#L28) and [export_book](https://github.com/kennethreitz/tablib/blob/46102d4be718ee6fd6c003c1387df7c940e65b2c/tablib/formats/_json.py#L33) fail with

        return json.dumps(dataset.dict, default=date_handler)

items.title: Unpickled Dataset results in unusable CSV and JSON exports
items.body:
```TypeError: <csv/json and probably more>() takes 0 positional arguments but 1 was given```

This happens after unpickling a pickled `Dataset` instance. More specifically, the pickling/unpickling process is through `rq` (http://python-rq.org/)

`.dict` would still work, and direct `repr/str` of the Dataset instance would still work.

items.title: Phone numbers and similar treated as numbers in XLSX export
items.body:
When textual data contains, e.g., phone numbers such as "0123456", these are exported as integers in XLSX format, thus making the 0 disappear in Excel, or, worse, showing them in scientific notation.

Here's an example:

```
tablib.Dataset(('a',10,'010'), headers=('A', 'B', 'C'))
```

This is exported correctly in XLS format, but wrongly in XLSX.

items.title: Row._data as OrderedDict to allow element access by label
items.body:
If headers are defined in a Dataset it would be helpful to allow element access within a row of the Dataset by column label in addition to index based access. Issue #22 suggested using namedtuples for this but --while acknowledging the general usefulness of such a feature-- was discarded because namedtuples would not support append, etc.

Implementing this via OrderedDicts should be possible though. It would require (it seems only in tablib/core.py on a first pass):

* Row constructor to accept an additional `headers` argument
* `_set_headers` to be augmented to update existing rows with new column labels
* Changes to Row methods `insert`,  `__getitem__`, `__setitem__`, and updates/changes to a few other special methods in Dataset and Row

It would introduce some overhead but given that Tablib is aimed at use cases "below" the Pandas level that might be acceptable and should not break the API.

I'm happy to give this a shot but --given that it will require changes in quite a few places in `core.py`-- would appreciate some feedback if (a) people still think that this would indeed be useful and (b) anyone sees a reason why doing this as outlined above is _not_ a good idea (or may not even work at all...).

Many thanks!

items.title: JSON export does not allow date and datetime values
items.body:
When exporting to JSON, `date` and `datetime` fields fail because `omnijson` does not support the `default` parameter (which points to an excellent function that converts to ISO string).

I'd say only use `omnijson` if there is no default json package, so in _json.py:

```
try:
    import json
except ImportError:
    from tablib.packages import omnijson as json
```

Or drop `omnijson` altogether since it only matters to Python <= 2.5 which is not even in the Travis matrix anymore.

items.title: Framework for adding input/output formats
items.body:
Right now, the list of formats is more or less hardcoded into the `formats.available` tuple, and it's not straightforward to extend (at least not to me).

It would be great if you could subclass an abstract `Formatter` class, and then either have it magically register (using some kind of metaclass magic, I suppose) with the available formats list or introduce a function and/or class decorator to explicitly register the new format.

Is that something you'd be interested in working on in the near term? I'd be happy to contribute some of my own time for it.

items.title: Generated XLSX files aren't valid XML when data includes escape sequences
items.body:
If a value such as `^D` is written as XLSX, invalid XML is generated and Excel complains. Excel's error: `Removed Part: /xl/sharedStrings.xml with XML error.  (Strings) Illegal xml character. Line 1, column 115.`

To reproduce:

``` python
import tablib
data = tablib.Dataset(headers=['test'])
data.append(['^D'])
with open('out.xlsx', 'wb') as f:
    f.write(data.xlsx)
```

Then try to open the file in Excel.

items.title: Support importing ragged CSV text into a Dataset
items.body:
Right now Dataset._validate prevents importing data where not all rows have the same width. This is not possible in some formats but is common in CSV files. Example:

``` python
from tablib import Dataset
from tablib.formats import csv
ds = Dataset()
csv.import_set(ds, "a,b,c\nx,y")
```

The result is:

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tablib/formats/_csv.py", line 48, in import_set
    dset.append(row)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tablib/core.py", line 668, in append
    self.rpush(row, tags)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tablib/core.py", line 652, in rpush
    self.insert(self.height, row=row, tags=tags)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tablib/core.py", line 643, in insert
    self._validate(row)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tablib/core.py", line 283, in _validate
    raise InvalidDimensions
tablib.core.InvalidDimensions
```

It may not be a good idea to actually represent ragged data in a Dataset, but it should be possible to import ragged CSV text into a uniform-width Dataset by filling in empty elements to make all rows match the width of the widest row.

items.title: Tablib import Excel NA() values as 42
items.body:
If you import an xls or xlsx file into a dataset using `import_set` or `import_sheet` and one of the cells contains a `NA()` error value then the value of the imported cell in the dataset is 42.

That's probably not what you want in any circumstance.

See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4928629/xlrd-excel-script-converting-n-a-to-42, for example.

You can work around that by changing:

```python
row_vals = [c.value for c in row]
```

to

```python
row_vals = [xlrd.error_text_from_code[c.value] if c.ctype == xlrd.XL_CELL_ERROR else c.value for c in row]
```

items.title: Dataset.transpose() fails if there are repeated headers
items.body:
If the same value appears multiple times in the headers of a Dataset, then when you `transpose()` it the values from the first time that header occurs are copied to all instances of it in the new Dataset. Although normally we wouldn't expect to have repeated headers, in the case of `transpose()` it seems quite likely, given that the initial header row is actually the first column of the Dataset you want. 

I would expect `Dataset.transpose().transpose()` to give me the original Dataset back. However:

``` python
import tablib
data = tablib.Dataset()
data.headers = ("first_name", "last_name", "age")
data.append(('John', 'Adams', 90))
data.append(('George', 'Washington', 67))
data.append(('John', 'Tyler', 71))
data.transpose().transpose().dict == data.dict
```

Which gives:

```
False
```

If we investigate in more detail:

```
data.transpose().transpose()['first_name']
data.transpose().transpose()['last_name']
data.transpose().transpose()['age']
```

We get:

```
['John', 'George', 'John']
['Adams', 'Washington', 'Adams']
[90, 67, 90]
```

The broken bit of `transpose()` is:

``` python
        for column in self.headers:

            if column == self.headers[0]:
                # It's in the headers, so skip it
                continue

            # Adding the column name as now they're a regular column
            row_data = [column] + self[column]
            row_data = Row(row_data)
            _dset.append(row=row_data)
```

If you replace that with:

``` python
        for index, column in enumerate(self.headers):

            if column == self.headers[0]:
                # It's in the headers, so skip it
                continue

            # Adding the column name as now they're a regular column
            # Use `get_col(index)` in case there are repeated values
            row_data = [column] + self.get_col(index)
            row_data = Row(row_data)
            _dset.append(row=row_data)
```

then it works as expected.

items.title: tablib embeds outdated packages

items.body:

``` python
import tablib

a = tablib.Dataset()
a.csv = "\nsome,test\ndata,here\n"
b = tablib.Dataset()
b.xls = a.xls
b.json
```

items.title: importing csv data with "foo, bar"
items.body:
quoting to escape `,` works fine for the first column but not for the second column..

`"foo, bar", hello` is read as `foo, bar`, `hello`

`hello, "foo, bar"` is read as `hello`, `"foo`, `bar"`
